title: 108_hr4843
content: The "Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2004" clarifies the jurisdiction of the Federal Government over waters of the United States, provides consistency nationwide, and consolidates authority in one Federal agency for implementing permitting programs under the Federal Water Pollution Act. Section 404(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to clarify the issuance of permits for waters of the United States, including navigable waters, waters hydrologically connected to navigable waters, and wetlands adjacent to navigable waters. This amendment ensures jurisdiction under the permitting program established by this section. The amendment to Section 404(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act clarifies that waters connected to navigable waters by perennial or intermittent streams are considered navigable waters. Excluded waters include sheet flow, ephemeral waters, groundwater, manmade ditches, pipelines, and certain storm sewer systems. The jurisdiction of the permitting program established by this section does not apply to connecting waters or fastlands. Individuals can request the Secretary to determine if their property contains waters subject to this jurisdiction. The Secretary may request additional information within 30 days of receiving a jurisdictional determination request. The Secretary must make a determination within 90 days of the initial request or 60 days after receiving additional information. The person submitting a request for a jurisdictional determination must receive written notification and documentation of the determination. They have the authority to seek immediate judicial review in the United States District Court if needed. Judicial review, injunctive relief, or administrative appeal may be sought for specified waters under the administrative appeals process. Any person who chooses the administrative appeals process retains the right to seek judicial review in the United States District Court. The final decision of the Secretary can be subject to judicial review under the administrative appeals process. SEC. 4. SINGLE AGENCY IMPLEMENTATION. Beginning on the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's authorities under section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act are transferred to the Secretary of the Army. The Administrator retains the authority to comment on permits issued under section 404(a) and general permits issued under section 404(e). All funds appropriated to the Administrator for these authorities are transferred to the Secretary. Conforming amendments are made to section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's authorities under section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act are transferred to the Secretary of the Army. No agreement under this subsection can elevate permit decisions above the District Engineer. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1344) is amended to include definitions for "navigable," "wetlands," and "adjacent wetlands." Navigable waters are those used for interstate commerce, wetlands are lands with hydric soils inundated by water, and adjacent wetlands are those physically touching wetlands. The curr_chunk provides definitions for "adjacent wetlands," "culvert," and "fastlands," specifying the characteristics and purposes of each term. Adjacent wetlands are wetlands physically touching specified waters, culverts are structures conveying streams under linear structures, and fastlands are areas behind manmade structures for commercial, industrial, or residential use.
